title: 106_hr1435
content: The "Small Business Banking Regulatory Relief Act of 1999" is the short title of this Act. It includes amendments related to savings and demand deposit accounts at depository institutions. The "Small Business Banking Regulatory Relief Act of 1999" includes amendments allowing depository institutions to permit up to 24 interaccount transfers per month for accounts with interest or dividends. The "Small Business Banking Regulatory Relief Act of 1999" allows depository institutions to permit up to 24 interaccount transfers per month for accounts with interest or dividends. Effective after September 30, 2001, section 2 of Public Law 93-100 is amended to include now accounts for all businesses. Withdrawals by negotiable or transferable instruments for transfers to third parties are permitted under section 2 of Public Law 93-100. Depository institutions can allow deposit owners to make withdrawals using negotiable or transferable instruments for payments to third parties. Lenders or servicers must pay interest on escrow accounts only if required by a contract or state law. Section 19(i) of the Federal Reserve Act is repealed, removing the prohibition on interest payments for demand deposits. The Federal Reserve Act, Home Owners' Loan Act, and Federal Deposit Insurance Act are amended to remove certain restrictions on savings associations. The amendments will take effect on October 1, 2001. SEC. 3. Payment of interest on reserves at Federal Reserve Banks. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow balances held at a Federal Reserve bank by depository institutions to earn interest, paid quarterly at a rate tied to the Federal Reserve System's securities portfolio earnings. The Board may establish regulations on these payments and distributions. The Board may prescribe regulations regarding the payment and distribution of earnings to depository institutions maintaining balances at Federal Reserve banks. In accordance with subsection (c)(1)(B), a Federal reserve bank can act on behalf of depository institutions that are not member banks. Amendments are made to sections 19(b)(4) and 19(c)(1)(A) of the Federal Reserve Act.
